title: 107_hr3172
content: The "Sales Tax Holiday Act of 2001" provides state sales tax relief for consumers. The "Sales Tax Holiday Act of 2001" reimburses eligible States for uncollected sales tax on tangible personal property from November 23 to December 2, 2001. States must inform the Secretary of the Treasury by November 15, 2001, verify uncollected tax by June 1, 2002, and have the Director of Management and Budget certify the amount for reimbursement. Eligible States cannot collect sales tax on taxable tangible property to qualify for reimbursement. To be eligible for reimbursement under the Sales Tax Holiday Act of 2001, States must not collect sales tax on taxable tangible personal property from November 23 to December 2, 2001, and comply with the Act's requirements. The Secretary of the Treasury will make an advance payment to eligible States by February 1, 2002, equal to 80% of the average sales tax collected in 1998, 1999, and 2000, with adjustments made to ensure the correct amount is paid. NEW YORK CITY SALES TAX RELIEF FOR CONSUMERS. The Secretary of the Treasury will reimburse New York City for uncollected municipal sales tax on taxable personal property from November 23, 2001, to December 2, 2001. The city must inform the Secretary by November 15, 2001, verify the uncollected tax by June 1, 2002, and have the amount certified by the Director of Management and Budget to qualify for reimbursement. The City of New York is eligible for reimbursement under subsection (a) if it does not collect municipal sales tax on taxable personal property from November 23, 2001, to December 2, 2001, and complies with the requirements of the Act. The Secretary of the Treasury will make an advance payment to the Mayor of New York City equal to 80 percent of the annual average sales tax collected in 1998, 1999, and 2000, with adjustments made to conform to the required payment under subsection (a). SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "sales tax" as a tax on retail sales of tangible property, "State" as any of the several States or territories, "taxable period" as a specific time frame, and "use tax" as a tax on the use of tangible property not subject to sales tax.
